awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP: Advanced Nanopositioning Stages for High-Throughput Semiconductor Metrology
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation – Research Partnerships (PFI-RP) project is to enable high-throughput inspection of semiconductor wafers via unprecedented positioning performance at an economically viable price-point. Process control, such as inspection of defects on semiconductor wafers, is currently a bottleneck for semiconductor manufacturing yield. Market demand for higher performance, increased functionality, smaller size, and lower prices in electronic chips has continued the push the industry towards smaller linewidths (currently at the 7 nm node) and more complex chip designs. This has resulted in an increasingly large number of defects per wafer, which impacts the chip functionality and therefore overall manufacturing yield. While it is desirable to inspect and evaluate more defects more frequently during the fabrication process to achieve high yield, the current slow rates of inspection lead to a throughput bottleneck. The technology developed via this project aims to overcome this tradeoff between inspection throughput and yield. The societal impact of this project will ultimately be in the form of cheaper electronics (processors, memory, sensors, etc.) that will broaden access to computers, mobile devices, automobiles, robotics, automation, and Internet of Things (IoT) devices, among others.  

The proposed project aims to develop nano-positioning technology that achieves a range of several millimeters of motion, high speed, smaller settling time, nanometric accuracy, and low heat generation – specifications previously considered impractical in a compact and cost-effective package. This project will develop nano-positioning stages that meet stringent motion specifications motivated by the needs of the semiconductor industry through innovations in parallel kinematic design, non-linear flexure mechanics, and structural dynamics with novel electromagnetic actuator architectures. These advanced nano-positioning stages will be incorporated within semiconductor process control equipment to rapidly move wafers from one defect to another.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this PFI-RP project has been to leverage basic research in flexure design, dynamics, and controls to develop and physically demonstrate advanced nanopositioning technology with unprecedented performance that can overcome semiconductor wafer metrology bottlenecks. Via a robust collaboration among academic and industrial partners, this project has helped develop nanopositioning stages that offer a combination of several millimeters motion range, nanometric accuracy and stability, ultra-fast speed and settling times, high payload capacity, and low heat generation – specifications that have thus far been considered impractical in a compact and cost-effective package.

The resulting nanopositioning technology will help the semiconductor manufacturing industry by enabling next-generation wafer metrology (e.g. defect review, inspection, overlay metrology) at progressively smaller feature sizes while increasing throughput. Higher metrology throughput will provide the much-needed yield improvement for chip manufacturers to meet the market drivers of ubiquitous and cheaper electronics in computers, mobile devices, automobiles, robotics, automation, and Internet of Things (IoT) devices.

This project has resulted novel flexure mechanism architectures, which are the subject of multiple patent applications and research publications. Multiple students and research engineers have received rigorous educational training and professional mentorship in engineering modeling, experimental methods, preparing and submitting patent applications and research manuscripts, technology transfer, customer discovery, and business model canvas development.


Last Modified: 02/28/2025
Modified by: Shorya Awtar
